pros:
A lot of great people and a great platform. Pre covid, some of the offices had a fun culture. The covid response has been very good. 

Some of the US benefits improved with Morgan Stanley. Has a smaller company feel with a large company's resources.

Some of the middle management is fantastic. If you get onto a great team with one of the good managers, it'll be a good job.
cons:
Ironically, US employees stopped getting stock awards with Morgan Stanley. Not even an espp! Some of the other benefits are surprisingly stingy. Add the 401k match once a year? Come on, you're in the business - that's a lot compounding power of that money the company is keeping for itself. 

The Morgan Stanley bureaucracy is stunningly difficult to work with. It can take weeks to get even simple communications approved. Gets in the way of good client service and support.

Upper management does all the talking and not much listening, so the employee fundamentals don't improve. For example, there is practically no career path for CSMs. 

There are definitely favorites, and if you're not one of the lucky few, be prepared to stay at the bottom of the pile. That's why some people have been there for a decade or more but in other groups turnover is high.

There's a turf battle with E*TRADE that's not pretty. Solium and E*TRADE were arch rivals and I don't think MS cared about what that was going to be like. Lots of legacy Solium leadership got pushed down a level so E*TRADE leadership could be inserted, which is not good optics.

pros: There is no reason that any one should work with Morgan Stanley. They just need the salves who can work day and nights.
cons: First of all I just want to tell the people who all are planning to join Morgan Stanley - Guys dont join this company if you are looking for a peaceful life. I joined in December 2020 and I left it in Feb 2020 (Exactly in 2 Months) .Its a completely unorganized organization. You will report to a person (So called your manager who dont know anything and will claim that he knows everything) and that person will treat you as a slave. Specially when you are on H1-B then NEVER join this company. They dont value the resource at all. They will expect you do everything in all the areas without any knowledge of that system/application. Also the expectation is that you will start your day at 8 AM in the morning and there is no time for the end of the day because you will need to attend the calls in the nights as well with the offshore teams. Your manager will forward you a meeting invite 12:30 AM in the night and will expect that you will join that meeting at 7 AM in the morning and if you are joining then he will misbehave.

cons:
Largest Downside: career development, and managerial decision making. 

E*TRADE is very risk averse, and this (while good for the company) fosters a negative client experience. 

The management (mid and senior level) seem to want to promote based on a "likeness" rather than merit, which causes a demoralized workforce.

pros: Good Environment and Employee Benefits
cons: Lack of opportunities and growth

pros:
People are always willing to lend a hand when you run into issues and will take large portions out of their day to make sure you understand concepts.

Compensation has gotten much better after the buy out happened. Big pockets of Morgan Stanley allows for higher salaries, and big bonuses (up to 20%). Also 100% RRSP match up to 6% of your salary. Benefits are pretty good so long as you don't need too much time with specialists.

Beer Fridays and bagel Mondays were a thing when working in the office.

Work life balance is good, I think I only worked overtime 2 or 3 times in the whole time I was there.
cons:
Management can vary in quality depending who you get as your boss. Some dev managers are great and always have your back when there's a problem. Others are spread too thin and don't have time to help all of their direct reports. Others aren't qualified for the position, haven't received the training but have the position because of their tenure at the company. Directors and up have been at the company so long and seem to be stuck in the small company feel. Managers outside of your section of the hierarchy have been unhelpful and negative in the past, which doesn't help organized cross team collaboration.

Tech debt piles up and is only looked at when it loses the company clients or money. New features are always pushed as an MVP with the thought that it will be improved later but sometimes is only improved months or years later. The tech stack is aging and while there's a push towards RESTful APIs, React, Redux and GraphQL it's moving slowly and management and some devs seem very resistant to pushing the change forwards. The monolith is huge and it's getting bigger faster than proper microservices can be moved out.

Retention and career advancement seems to be a mystery in how it is managed. I've seen offers to retain at less than 50% of a salary bump compared to an outside offer for very strong employees for some while tens of thousand salary bumps are given for others. You have to fight extremely hard to get any raise over 2%. If you want a raise get an offer from another company and you should be able to get a raise within 2 weeks as opposed to 6-12 months. Haven't experienced it first hand but it I have heard that gender has a large effect on your salary and bonuses which is very disappointing. It was really poor that the 5 week was sabbatical was taken away with such an arbitrary cut off. Especially since so many people were hired when Morgan Stanley and UBS were white label deals (pre buy out) and they got the company to the point where Morgan Stanley bought it. They helped grow the company and then their future sabbaticals were taken away. Very poor move from my point of view.

Dev superstars are given a huge amount of praise and lots of the company's direction is pinned on these people. If they put in the extra hours they get the recognition. This has lead to some pretty toxic people getting senior roles in the dev team, it's sad to see that people who put down their coworkers are rewarded.
QAs are also treated poorly despite that fact that they hold a huge amount of domain knowledge and allow the software to be released in a much better state.

Post buy out brought in a lot of restrictions to devs. No sudo access on machines, limited software allowed when working from home, really reduces productivity.

Finally wanted to speak about the CEO Marcos Lopez. When I first started at the company he seemed like a very compassionate person who wanted the best for his company and the people who were there. Granted he has always had a reputation for being tightfisted, the AGM parties and holiday parties were always well done and found a way to show appreciation. As time went on he seemed to change to someone who cared more about the money of the company. One instance that stands out is when the buy out was happening and we were told out grants would be accelerated which I acknowledge it wasn't something Morgan Stanley had to do he said something along the lines of "It was really nice that they did this, I wouldn't have done that." Which is just a terrible thing to say to the people who helped you net a few ten millions off the sale of your company.

review_title: Shameful culture - never trust in this company
pros: Nice office, however lack of personal space (open office).
cons:

The team failed to complete its task by the deadline and the managers tried to blame me for their mismanagement. They put together false performance reviews to fire me, but I quit before they could push this thru. Never trust in your colleagues or managers here. 
Other people were also fired or demoted based on false/fake performance/"360" reviews. If you find yourself in that situation go to the court immediately and file a lawsuit against Morgan Stanley.
